text: RT @JoaquinCastrotx This moment captures what it’s like for women in CBP custody to share a cramped cell—some held for 50 days—for them to be denied showers for up to 15 days and life-saving medication. For some, it also means being separated from their children. This is El Paso Border Station #1. http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1145843515521404928/pu/img/dcYPAa7p182G3Cd2.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1145843515521404928/pu/vid/272x480/2Sen7bXlDuLaF-gs.mp4?tag=10

RT @RepJudyChu "If you want water, just drink from a toilet." That's what border patrol told one thirsty woman we met on today's #DemsAtTheBorder trip. These are the same CBP personnel who threatened to throw burritos at members of Congress. Changes must be made. #DontLookAway http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1145779178236719104/img/rFe8kA8hdCROgUHD.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1145779178236719104/vid/320x568/B7RiIL8cb6kB7ZR7.mp4?tag=13

What’s haunting is that the women I met with today told me in no uncertain terms that they would experience retribution for telling us what they shared.

They all began sobbing - out of fear of being punished, out of sickness, out of desperation, lack of sleep, trauma, despair.

Now I’ve seen the inside of these facilities.

It’s not just the kids. It’s everyone. People drinking out of toilets, officers laughing in front of members Congress.

I brought it up to their superiors. They said “officers are under stress & act out sometimes.” No accountability.

CBP made us check our phones.

But one woman slipped me this packet to take with me. 

It says “shampoo,” but she told me that this is all they give women to wash their entire body. Nothing else.

Some women’s hair was falling out. Others had gone 15 days without taking a shower. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D-a1WoqWkAAMd3j.jpg

These officers felt brazen in there. While mgmt was telling us it was a “secure facility” where *members of Congress* had to check their phones, we caught officers trying to sneak photos, laughing.

CBP’s “good” behavior was toxic. Imagine how they treat the women trapped inside. https://twitter.com/saikatc/status/1145808500892811265 QT @saikatc Imagine all your hateful trolls online, but with guns. Imagine walking into a fenced area full of them. No exit. You don't get to take any cameras or phones with you. And those trolls with guns? They're the ones in charge of protecting you. 

That's what @AOC faced today. https://twitter.com/justicedems/status/1145803146591121408

RT @RepDean Just left the first CBP facility. The conditions are far worse than we ever could have imagined. 

15 women in their 50s- 60s sleeping in a small concrete cell, no running water. Weeks without showers. All of them separated from their families. 

This is a human rights crisis.

Just left the 1st CBP facility.

I see why CBP officers were being so physically &sexually threatening towards me.

Officers were keeping women in cells w/ no water & had told them to drink out of the toilets.

This was them on their GOOD behavior in front of members of Congress.

And to these CBP officers saying they felt “threatened” by me -

They were literally discussing making a GoFundMe for an officer who attacked my on my tour.

They confiscated my phone, and they were all armed. I’m 5’4”.

They’re just upset I exposed their inhumane behavior.
